did.unittitle: Fred E. Benz motion picture collection 1929-1950
did.abstract: Amateur photographer; sixty-two reels of film shot by Benz on various trips.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The films were received as part of the University of Michigan Media Resources Center Collection (Donor no. 4408).

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are not expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Fred E. Benz motion picture collection, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: In 1911, Fred Benz, an Ann Arbor, Michigan native, joined his brothers Victor and Albert in their agricultural implements and feed business called Benz Brothers. Throughout the teens, the brothers expanded their interests into the area of automotive accessories, and in the early twenties opened a Chevrolet dealership. Fred retained an interest in the business but relinquished the operation of Benz Brothers to Albert and became the treasurer of the Ann Arbor Finance Company in 1928. In 1931, he left that position and became vice-president and secretary of The National Company of Ann Arbor. He retired in 1932 but retained his interest in the Benz Brothers operation. Very little additional information exists relating to Benz. He married in 1916 to a woman named Margaret and the marriage lasted until his death in 1963. Benz probably had an interest and skill in photography judging by the quality of the images and the ability with the camera displayed on the rolls of film in this collection.

scopecontent.p: When the University of Michigan Media Resources Collection was accessioned by the Bentley Historical Library, a number of films were discovered in the vault that were not related to that collection. Within that material were travel films shot by Fred E. Benz. These films, covering the period 1929 to 1950, allow the viewer to experience the sights of the world and its people at those moments in time. The films had been edited together and were probably used by Benz for presentation to local groups and as home entertainment.

The Fred E. Benz Collection contains sixty-two, 400 foot reels of silent 16mm film. It is made up of eight series, one for each trip taken. The series are: Africa, Australia/New Zealand, Guatemala, Havana, Mexico, Russia, South America, and a World Cruise. The contents of each reel are described in the finding aid. Benz has included handwritten descriptions of the images found on the Russian and World Cruise series attached to the inside lids of each can of film. Benz was careful to document most of the locations with a handwritten note displayed before the camera. When cities or natural markers are noted in the finding aid, the identifying information was taken from that supplied by the film maker on the screen or from his notes in the can lids. The spelling of geographic locations in the finding aid reflect the information on the film and not current spellings.

Short notes found with the Mexican footage indicate it was the result of two different trips. The reels retain their original numbering because the numbered reels (1,2,3,4) appear to comprise one trip and numbered/lettered reels (1a, 3a, 4a) comprise the second trip.

The value of the collection is that it captures moments in time, documenting lifestyles, architecture and modes of travel which no longer exist or have evolved over time. Footage exists of London on the eve of war and Shanghai one year before being destroyed by the Japanese invasion.

Perhaps the greater value lies in the depiction of the indigenous lifestyles captured on film. Benz, as an amateur photographer, was interested in the common events that he experienced as he traveled. He captured human life as it went on around him. The collection features extensive footage of people working or playing and children of different cultures going about their daily activities. The films show barren huts in remote areas of Russia in the 1930s, families living under stone bridges outside of Buenos Aires, life-saving competitions in Sydney and the plethora of street markets found in most cultures and countries that he traveled through.

Because these are travel films, the scope of the footage included often extends beyond the geographic area used to identify the series. For example, the Australia footage includes material filmed on various Pacific islands, the Asian continent and Japan. The Russian trip contains footage of England and Northern Europe, and the South American films contain shots of the departure from New York. Each series should be examined for additional geographic content.

Special attention should be given to the Mexican series containing footage of Mt. Rushmore with construction only partially complete. Included as well are extensive shots of bullfighting in addition to other Mexican scenes. Also of note is the extensive depiction of women throughout all of the series. On the canister containing reel 5 in the Russia series is a receipt from United States Navy Department stating that this reel was being forwarded to Chicago for study of the shots of Kirkenes, Norway.

The color in the Africa, Guatemala, Havana, Mexico and South America series is excellent. The wide, clean, lush cityscapes of Havana and Capetown are richly captured in color and give an indication why they were popular travel destinations at this time.

In addition to the eight travel series, the collection also included one reel of World War II footage assembled by Castle Films from public domain footage. This type of film was sold through camera stores and mail order houses and Benz probably purchased a reel for his own use. The identifying writing on the film can is in Benz's handwriting and clearly belonged with his collection.

odd.p: [Mombasa (street scenes, stone cutting, native section); Nairobi (street scenes); Namonga River Camp; mirage; Gethins Rhino Camp.]
Animals (rhino, zebra, elephants, etc.); Moshi (street market, natives); Mount Kilimanjaro.)]
[Animals (lions, lions eating zebra, wildebeest, secretary bird); Safari Camp.]
[Animals (hippo, ostrich); Makuru: Kampala: native villages; children; native dress.]
[Lake Kivel; volcano with hardened lava; pygmies (chief, family, dances); animals (hippo).]
[Velt; Murcherson Falls; the Nile River; Mwanza (children play soccer, cemetery, natives carry heavy loads); animals (crocodiles and eggs, hippo, giant ant hills).]
[Africa-Kigoma; Ujiji; Stanley monument; Albertville; women in chains; women washing clothes in stream; native homes; native musicians; Elizabethville; Victoria Falls; Cecil Rhodes' grave.]
[Capetown (pan of city, flower market, German embassy, houses, churches, street scene); Lobito (natives cooking, selling hides).]
[Las Palmas (street scenes, houses and buildings, penguins being shipped, military band on parade).]
Shipboard; Hawaii; Fiji (Suva) (rice planting, native huts); Aukland.
New Zealand (steam spouts, native villages, caves).

[Wellington (street scenes, Wellington monument, buildings); Sydney (street scenes, Peters Ice Cream Co., horse racing track and stables, Jenolan Caves, life-saving and rescue competition, Charles Farrell (actor).]
[Thursday Island (native villages, native body markings); Java (women washing clothes in stream, men bathing, village life, rice planting).]
Jakarta (street scenes, street market, children at play); Singapore (street scenes, post office, monkeys); Bangkok (street scenes, native performers, temples).]
[Brisbane, Australia (pan of city and countryside); animals (snakes, kangaroos, Koala bears); boomerang thrower; native huts.]
[Bali (natives grinding grain, farming, children playing, temples and ruins, native dances).]
[Hong Kong (harbor, street scenes, buildings, natives fishing); Canton (harbor and junks, street scenes).]
[Shanghai (harbor, street scenes); Peiping (street scenes, camels, cars and bikes); The Great Wall.]
[Beppu (Japan) (street scenes, tea garden, hot springs); Kobe; Kyoto (gardens, street scenes, children playing); Nara (street scenes, deer herds in park); Tokyo (street scenes, family picnic).]
[Tokyo (street scenes, hot springs, native dances); Yokahama (street scenes); Hawaii; Hilo (waterfalls).]
Hilo (hilo crater, long shot of city); shipboard to US; long shot of Golden Gate Bridge.

[Aerial shots of Guatemala; Guatemala City (street scenes, parks, churches, buildings); rural scenes (making brick and tile, washing clothes in stream, men carry pots on their back); Atitla (houses, gardens, native dress).]

[Villages (street scenes, women washing clothes and self in stream); Santiago (street market, church, weaving, thatching a roof); Quetzltenaorgo (sweeping pan of city, street scenes, carrying water, street market, church); farms; Huemuetenanca (city square, Mayan ruins)]

[Unnamed village (street scenes, street market, potter making bowls); rural houses; Sacapilas (children playing, village scenes); Chichicastenango (pan of village, church, funeral procession, cemetery, children play basketball, street market, religious ceremony-possibly Easter).]
[Solola (pan of city, street market, women carry produce and turkeys to market); Antiqua (street scenes, park, Easter ceremony, churches, gardens, children playing soccer).]
[Pan of city; street scenes; gardens; monuments; street peddlers; cemetery; Sloppy Joe's Bar]
[Monuments; cemetery; Rio Crystal Club; gardens; poor sections of town; sugar cane harvest; pineapple plants; children spinning tops; rural scenes.]
[Monterrey (pan across city, street scenes, poor section of town); Saltillo (street scenes, parks, gardens); Xochimilico (canals, flower covered boats, floating market and musicians).]
[Nuevo Laredo (adobe huts, ropemaking, church, waterfall); Montemoreoos (orange groves, street market, church).]
[Acapulco; Pagoyo (deep sea fishing, street market, pan of village); working in the fields; women wash clothes in canal; native costumes.]
[San Juan (village scenes, land covered with volcanic dust); volcano erupting (very dark and difficult to see).]
[Paco (street scenes, street market, women washing clothes); Patzcuaro (street market, street performer, natives sewing fishnets); Morelia (street scenes, women washing); scenes of the countryside.]
[Mexico City (street scenes, street market, church, the members of the Equestrian Club, bullfight); Taxco (pan across city, church).]

[Puebla (street scenes); unidentified sea coast; empty prairie; Mt. Rushmore (working on the figures, scaffolding hanging across faces); Grotlo Geyser; Old Faithful Geyser; Holland, MI (beds of tulips).]

[Leaving New York (Statue of Liberty); London (this section alternates between b&w and color stock) (street scenes, newspaper headlines, buildings, changing of the guard); The Hague (milk delivered by wagon, gardens, street scenes); Moneakandam (women wash clothes in stream, native dress).]
[Holland; Berlin (street scenes, zoo, women streetcleaners, Berlin stadium); train trip to Warsaw; Warsaw (street scenes, buildings women pushing carts, funeral).]
[Moscow (Red Square, street scenes); Gorki (street scenes, park, barges along river, a large funeral); rural life along the Volga River.]

[Stalingrad (street scenes, people drawing water at public well); farms; Rostov; Ordjonikidze (street scene, buildings); rural countryside; sheep herders; baby bear cubs; Tiflis (aerial shot of city, street scenes, children playing); Batum (street scenes, people on beach).]

Helsingfors (Finland) (street scenes, buildings, pan across city); Rovaniemi (street scenes, rural scenes); Ivano (Lapland) (carved sleigh, luggage on horse drawn cart, ruins of recent hotel fire); Kirkenes (Norway) (pan of city and bay, street scenes, "City Center", pan of wharf and city from ship).]

[Unidentified fishing village; Hammerfest (Norway) (pans of the harbor, fish market, street scenes); Trondheim (street markets, trains); Bergen (old world architecture, street scenes, street market); men cutting hay; women drying hay.]

Bergen (street scenes); train trip from Bergen to Oslo; Oslow (this section alternates between b&w and color stock) (street scenes, Leiv Eiriksson airplane wreckage, gardens, outdoor restaurant, 20th Century Fox film exchange, buildings, zoo with polar and brown bears, folk costumes, folk dancing).]
[Copenhagen (entire reel alternates between b&w and color) (street scenes, gardens, street vendors, pan across city).]

Leaving New York (Statue of Liberty); Ceremonies for crossing the Equator; Rio de Janeiro (Rotary Club of Brazil, pan across the harbor, pan of city, aerial cable car, beaches, race track, street scenes, buildings, zoo with monkeys and tapers); Quitandiula Hotel.]
[Santos (street scenes, zoo, beach, pan of city); San Paulo (snakes); Montevideo (street scenes, buildings); Buenos Aires (street scenes, buildings, street market).]

[Buenos Aires (Street scenes, poor part of town, children at play, cemetery, tombs, funeral, churches, pan of city). Port of Spain (tropical birds and flowers, women and children, native huts, gardens, street scenes, street performers); rural life.]

[Ship leaves New York; Gibraltar; Algiers (street scenes, native women dancing,); Monaco (pan of city, hills and fields); Nice (pan of city, boardwalk area); Naples; Athens; (Acropolis, Mars Hill, Temple Of Jupiter, Tower of the Winds)]
[Athens (street scenes, women at well); Jerusalem (churches, street scenes, nomads); Dead Sea; camels; pyramids; sphinx.]
[Cairo (zoo); The Nile River; Bombay (zoo, children playing, men bathing in river, street scenes, native dress, railroad station); Delhi.]
[Delhi (German cannons, Taj Mahal, tonga snakes Benares (Holy men covered with ashes); Agra (street market, peasant houses); Kenares (hair cutting, men and women bathing).]
[Calcutta (people mourning the dead, man with leprosy, cobra-mongoose fight, temples, ape smoking, women bathing); Darjeeling (crushing stone for asphalt, women porters).]
[Darjeeling (dancing bear, women carrying water); Madras (street scenes, dog and monkey cart); Madura (street scenes).]
[Colombo (Ceylon) (street scenes, seascapes, native dances); Kandy (elephants working); Sumatra (kick boxing demonstration, native ceremonies, train trip).]
[Buytenzong (Java) (street scenes, harvesting, women washing clothes, steam trains); ceremonies crossing the equator (shipboard ritual).]
[Singapore (native police, street scenes, pineapple market, rubber extraction); Siam; Bangkok (elephants, monkeys, temples, native costumes, native dances, native musicians); Manila (waterfront).]
[Manila (street scenes, cockfight); ricefields; Hong Kong (harbor, pan of city); Canton (street scenes).]

[Hinwangtao (China) (railroad yards); Tangshan (railroad station, local merchants): Peiping (Forbidden City, street scenes, street performers, Summer Palace, Winter Palace, Temple of Heaven, grinding meal) The Great Wall.]

[Peiping (street scenes, water wagon); Beppu (street scenes, native dress, welcoming crowd at train station); Kobe (Japan) (street scenes, street market, woman and child); Kyoto (street scenes, gardens, temples); Nara (street scenes, rickshaws, large heard of deer in city park).]

[Nara (street scenes); Yokohama (street scenes, waterways, drilling a well); Kamakura (street market, people at rail station to see soldiers depart); Nikko (temples, children going to school, Kanaya Hotel); Tokyo (soldiers marching, street scenes, Japanese Boy Scouts).]
[Honolulu (street scenes, passengers debarking the ship, buildings, gardens); Panama Canal; Balboa (statue of Balboa, locks of the canal).]
[Hilo (waterfalls, fern jungle, volcano); shipboard activities and passengers.]

[Stanford University; U.S. Fleet in San Pedro; Long Beach oil wells; Cristabal; Havana (port area, Sloppy Joe's Bar, pan of city from ship); Ann Arbor (train station, downtown pan up First National Bank and Trust Company, Liberty Street facing west (includes Michigan Theater).]

did.unittitle: Russia Stops Hitler, Castle Films, undated,

odd.p: [Castle Films, commercial newsreel footage depicting the German invasion of Russia and the eventual counterattack by Soviet troops (1941-1943) from the Russian viewpoint; consists primarily of combat footage]
